title: Programming in Base R
text:
Create vectors for pre- and post-treatment blood pressure values:


bp_pre <- c( 120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)
bp_pre

 [1] 120 151 125 126 115 132 132 129 134 139 127 122 127 135 133 128 147 138 140
[20] 132

bp_post <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)
bp_post

 [1] 127 145 135 122 115 122 123 126 126 129 132 146 120 114 121 120 128 120 133
[20] 115



Assign names to the vectors:


names(bp_pre) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")
bp_pre

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 

names(bp_post) <- paste("Subject",1:20, sep = "_")
bp_post

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 



Calculate the change in blood pressure for each subject and store in a vector:


bp_change = bp_pre - bp_post
bp_change

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
        -7          6        -10          4          0         10          9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
         3          8         10         -5        -24          7         21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
        12          8         19         18          7         17 



Calculate average decrease in blood pressure for all subjects:


avg_decrease <- mean(bp_change)
avg_decrease

[1] 5.65



Determine which subjects experienced a decrease in blood pressure:


which(bp_change > 0)

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         2          4          6          7          8          9         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
        13         14         15         16         17         18         19 
Subject_20 
        20 



Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change:


index_vec <- bp_change > 0
pos_bp_change <- bp_change[index_vec]
pos_bp_change

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 



Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those values where the blood pressure decreased (positive change):


avg_pos_diff <- mean(pos_bp_change)
avg_pos_diff

[1] 10.6

title: Programming in Base R
text:
Create vectors for pre- and post-treatment blood pressure values:


bp_pre <- c( 120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)
bp_pre

 [1] 120 151 125 126 115 132 132 129 134 139 127 122 127 135 133 128 147 138 140
[20] 132

bp_post <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)
bp_post

 [1] 127 145 135 122 115 122 123 126 126 129 132 146 120 114 121 120 128 120 133
[20] 115



Assign names to the vectors:


names(bp_pre) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")
bp_pre

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 

names(bp_post) <- paste("Subject",1:20, sep = "_")
bp_post

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 



Calculate the change in blood pressure for each subject and store in a vector:


bp_change = bp_pre - bp_post
bp_change

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
        -7          6        -10          4          0         10          9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
         3          8         10         -5        -24          7         21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
        12          8         19         18          7         17 



Calculate average decrease in blood pressure for all subjects:


avg_decrease <- mean(bp_change)
avg_decrease

[1] 5.65



Determine which subjects experienced a decrease in blood pressure:


which(bp_change > 0)

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         2          4          6          7          8          9         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
        13         14         15         16         17         18         19 
Subject_20 
        20 



Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change:


index_vec <- bp_change > 0
pos_bp_change <- bp_change[index_vec]
pos_bp_change

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 



Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those values where the blood pressure decreased (positive change):


avg_pos_diff <- mean(pos_bp_change)
avg_pos_diff

[1] 10.6

title: Programming in Base R
text:
Task 2: Basic Data Frame Practice

Create a data frame object with four columns corresponding to the previous data: patient, pre_bp, post_bp, and diff_bp.


bp_data <- data.frame(patient = names(bp_pre),pre_bp = bp_pre,post_bp = bp_post,diff_bp = bp_change)
bp_data

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
Subject_2   Subject_2    151     145       6
Subject_3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
Subject_4   Subject_4    126     122       4
Subject_5   Subject_5    115     115       0
Subject_6   Subject_6    132     122      10
Subject_7   Subject_7    132     123       9
Subject_8   Subject_8    129     126       3
Subject_9   Subject_9    134     126       8
Subject_10 Subject_10    139     129      10
Subject_11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
Subject_12 Subject_12    122     146     -24
Subject_13 Subject_13    127     120       7
Subject_14 Subject_14    135     114      21
Subject_15 Subject_15    133     121      12
Subject_16 Subject_16    128     120       8
Subject_17 Subject_17    147     128      19
Subject_18 Subject_18    138     120      18
Subject_19 Subject_19    140     133       7
Subject_20 Subject_20    132     115      17

rownames(bp_data) <- 1:20 # Subject_1 to Subject_20 were the row names as well as the patient values for data frame bp_data after creation, so I changed the row names to the numbers 1 to 20.
bp_data

      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
2   Subject_2    151     145       6
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
4   Subject_4    126     122       4
5   Subject_5    115     115       0
6   Subject_6    132     122      10
7   Subject_7    132     123       9
8   Subject_8    129     126       3
9   Subject_9    134     126       8
10 Subject_10    139     129      10
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24
13 Subject_13    127     120       7
14 Subject_14    135     114      21
15 Subject_15    133     121      12
16 Subject_16    128     120       8
17 Subject_17    147     128      19
18 Subject_18    138     120      18
19 Subject_19    140     133       7
20 Subject_20    132     115      17



Return only rows of the data frame where the diff_bp column is negative.


index_vec_2 <- bp_data$diff_bp < 0
bp_data[index_vec_2,]

      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24



Add a new column to the data frame corresponding to TRUE if the post_bp is less than 120 and FALSE if it is not:


bp_data$less_than_120 <- ifelse(bp_data$post_bp < 120,"TRUE","FALSE")
bp_data

      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp less_than_120
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7         FALSE
2   Subject_2    151     145       6         FALSE
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10         FALSE
4   Subject_4    126     122       4         FALSE
5   Subject_5    115     115       0          TRUE
6   Subject_6    132     122      10         FALSE
7   Subject_7    132     123       9         FALSE
8   Subject_8    129     126       3         FALSE
9   Subject_9    134     126       8         FALSE
10 Subject_10    139     129      10         FALSE
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5         FALSE
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24         FALSE
13 Subject_13    127     120       7         FALSE
14 Subject_14    135     114      21          TRUE
15 Subject_15    133     121      12         FALSE
16 Subject_16    128     120       8         FALSE
17 Subject_17    147     128      19         FALSE
18 Subject_18    138     120      18         FALSE
19 Subject_19    140     133       7         FALSE
20 Subject_20    132     115      17          TRUE



Make a nice print out of data frame:


knitr::kable(bp_data)

pre_bp
post_bp
diff_bp

title: Programming in Base R
text:
Task 3: List Practice

Create a new data frame for placebo values:


Create vectors for columns of data frame
Combine vectors into data frame
View data frame


patient <- paste("Placebo", 1:10, sep = " ")
pre_bp_pl <- c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130)
post_bp_pl <- c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124)
diff_bp_pl <- pre_bp_pl - post_bp_pl
less_than_120_pl <- ifelse(post_bp_pl < 120,"TRUE","FALSE")

placebo_df <- data.frame(patient,pre_bp_pl,post_bp_pl,diff_bp_pl,less_than_120_pl)

placebo_df

      patient pre_bp_pl post_bp_pl diff_bp_pl less_than_120_pl
1   Placebo 1       138        105         33             TRUE
2   Placebo 2       135        136         -1            FALSE
3   Placebo 3       147        123         24            FALSE
4   Placebo 4       117        130        -13            FALSE
5   Placebo 5       152        134         18            FALSE
6   Placebo 6       134        143         -9            FALSE
7   Placebo 7       114        135        -21            FALSE
8   Placebo 8       121        139        -18            FALSE
9   Placebo 9       131        120         11            FALSE
10 Placebo 10       130        124          6            FALSE



Create and store a list with two elements:


First element named treatment containing data frame bp_data
Second element named placebo containing data frame placebo_df


bp_study <- list(treatment = bp_data, placebo = placebo_df)
bp_study

$treatment
      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp less_than_120
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7         FALSE
2   Subject_2    151     145       6         FALSE
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10         FALSE
4   Subject_4    126     122       4         FALSE
5   Subject_5    115     115       0          TRUE
6   Subject_6    132     122      10         FALSE
7   Subject_7    132     123       9         FALSE
8   Subject_8    129     126       3         FALSE
9   Subject_9    134     126       8         FALSE
10 Subject_10    139     129      10         FALSE
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5         FALSE
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24         FALSE
13 Subject_13    127     120       7         FALSE
14 Subject_14    135     114      21          TRUE
15 Subject_15    133     121      12         FALSE
16 Subject_16    128     120       8         FALSE
17 Subject_17    147     128      19         FALSE
18 Subject_18    138     120      18         FALSE
19 Subject_19    140     133       7         FALSE
20 Subject_20    132     115      17          TRUE

$placebo
      patient pre_bp_pl post_bp_pl diff_bp_pl less_than_120_pl
1   Placebo 1       138        105         33             TRUE
2   Placebo 2       135        136         -1            FALSE
3   Placebo 3       147        123         24            FALSE
4   Placebo 4       117        130        -13            FALSE
5   Placebo 5       152        134         18            FALSE
6   Placebo 6       134        143         -9            FALSE
7   Placebo 7       114        135        -21            FALSE
8   Placebo 8       121        139        -18            FALSE
9   Placebo 9       131        120         11            FALSE
10 Placebo 10       130        124          6            FALSE



Access the first element of the list using three different types of syntax:


bp_study[1]

$treatment
      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp less_than_120
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7         FALSE
2   Subject_2    151     145       6         FALSE
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10         FALSE
4   Subject_4    126     122       4         FALSE
5   Subject_5    115     115       0          TRUE

19 Subject_19    140     133       7         FALSE
20 Subject_20    132     115      17          TRUE

In one line of code, access the pre_bp_pl column of the placebo data set in the list:


bp_study$placebo$pre_bp_pl

 [1] 138 135 147 117 152 134 114 121 131 130
